title: 104_hr4016
content: The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" is cited as the short title. It amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include State Grants for Drug and Violence Prevention Programs. This includes reservations and allotments for these programs. The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" reserves funds for specific programs, including grants for Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Northern Mariana Islands, programs for Indian youth, a national impact evaluation, and programs for Native Hawaiians. State allotments are also specified. The Secretary allocates funds among States based on school-aged population ratios and previous year's funding received under part A of title I. No State shall receive less than one-half of 1 percent of the total amount allotted to all States. The Secretary may reallot funds to States if unable to use within two years. Definitions include 'State' as 50 states, DC, and Puerto Rico, and 'local educational agency' as educational service agencies. SEC. 4112. STATE APPLICATIONS. To receive funding under section 4111, the State's chief executive officer must submit an application to the Secretary. The application must describe how funds will be coordinated with other programs, provide results of the State's needs assessment for drug and violence prevention, and assure cooperation with the Secretary in conducting a national impact assessment. The Secretary will conduct a national impact evaluation of programs required by section 4114(a) and use a peer review process for reviewing State applications under this section. "State programs under SEC. 4113 are subject to a peer review process for reviewing State applications." The chief executive officer of a State must use allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs. Administrative costs are limited to 5% of the total amount received. Grants are exclusively for financing prevention or education programs on the dangers of illegal drug use and underage drinking. The chief executive officer of a State must use allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs, with penalties for misapplication of funds. Grants or contracts awarded are subject to peer review. The chief executive officer may use funds directly or through grants/contracts for law enforcement education partnerships. Grants are awarded to law enforcement agencies in consortium with educational or community-based agencies for drug abuse and violence prevention activities, including programs like Drug Abuse Resistance Education and Legal Lives. District attorneys provide classroom instruction in the law and legal system, emphasizing interactive learning techniques like mock trial competitions, partnerships between law enforcement and child guidance professionals, and before- and after-school activities. "District attorneys provide classroom instruction in the law and legal system, emphasizing interactive learning techniques like mock trial competitions, partnerships between law enforcement and child guidance professionals, and before- and after-school activities. SEC. 4114. EVALUATION AND REPORTING." The Secretary conducts a biennial evaluation of national impact of programs combating school violence, collecting data on violence frequency and seriousness in elementary and secondary schools. The Secretary evaluates national school violence programs biennially, collecting data on violence in schools. States must submit reports on program implementation and effectiveness every three years, with recommendations and cost estimates due by January 1, 2000. The Secretary evaluates national school violence programs biennially, collecting data on prevalence of drug use and violence by youth in schools and communities, which must be made readily available to the public. The Secretary shall make grants or agreements with organizations serving Native Hawaiians to administer programs for their benefit. Native Hawaiian is defined as individuals with ancestors native to Hawaii before 1778.
